content.text: Pour an estimated \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A. Use the markings on the beaker as a guide
Place the thermometer in the water in beaker A
Record, in the first row of Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch
Record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\) , \(t = 60 \text{s}\) , \(t = 90 \text{s}\) , \(t = 120 \text{s}\) , \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer from the beaker
Repeat the procedure in (a)(i) for beaker B
Suggest one possible source of inaccuracy in the procedure, even if it is carried out carefully
beaker A
Write a conclusion describing the effect of changing the size of the beaker on the rate of cooling of the hot water
Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
Students in other schools do the same experiment **using identical apparatus**
State **one** variable that they need to control in order to obtain readings as close as possible to your readings
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x\) for beaker B
Use your readings **for beaker B** in Table 1.1 and the equation
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
A student thinks that more thermal energy is lost from the surface of the water in beaker B than from the sides of beaker B
Suggest an additional experiment that she can do with beaker B to test her idea. You are not required to do this additional experiment
Suggest how the cooling rate of the water in beaker B in this additional experiment compares with the value of \(x\) in (d) if her idea is correct
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water in different sized beakers
Refer to Fig. 1.1
Attach the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
Close the switch
Measure the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_0\) across the resistor for \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\)
Open the switch
Adjust the position of the crocodile clip on the resistance wire to a length \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\). Close the switch
Measure and record, in Table 2.1, the value of the current \(I\) in the circuit
Measure and record, in Table 2.1, values of the current \(I\) for \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\)
Open the switch
Plot a graph of \(l / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / \text{A}\) (\(x\)-axis)
Draw a best-fit straight line. You do not need to start the axes at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the resistor
Use your value of \(V_0\) from **(a)** and the equation
Suggest one practical reason why other students might not obtain the same result as you, even if they do the experiment carefully
The resistance wire can become very hot during this type of experiment
Suggest one change to the apparatus that prevents this
In this experiment, you will determine the resistance of a resistor
The circuit has been set up for you
Refer to Fig. 2.1

Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) as indicated by Fig. 3.1. Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet

Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\), \(2\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Extend the normal downwards until it crosses the line \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label the point at which it crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NE}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1, \(7\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 15^{\circ}\) to the normal
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in (a)

Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line **NE**, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)

View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block, from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear exactly one behind the other
Mark with crosses and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Remove the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet
Draw a straight line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend this line to cross **NF**
Label the point at which this line meets **NF** with the letter **G**. Label the point at which this line crosses **CD** with the letter **H**
Join points \(\mathbf{H}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\) with a straight line
Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{HN}\)
Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{HG}\)
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index. Use the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)
n =
Draw a new line **NE**, as indicated by Fig. 3.1, \(7 \text{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_2 = 40^\circ\) to the normal
Repeat the steps in **(b)**. Extend the new line **HG** until it crosses the line **HG** from **(b)**
Measure \(\alpha\), the acute angle between the line **HG** from **(b)** and the line **HG** from **(d)**. (An acute angle is always less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to the difference between angle \(\theta_2\) from **(d)** and angle \(\theta_1\) from **(a)**
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
Suggest one technique to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. Tie your ray-trace sheet into this Booklet between pages 8 and 9
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block
You will determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block
Use the separate ray-trace sheet provided
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
A student investigates the speed of a small trolley moving down a sloping ramp
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of different angles of slope on the average speed of the trolley between points on the ramp
Average speed can be calculated from the equation:
The apparatus available includes:
· a long ramp with a support that enables it to be set at different angles of slope
· a small trolley
You are **not** required to do the experiment
In your plan:
· list any additional apparatus needed
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including how to take the measurements so that the average speed can be determined
· suggest a possible source of inaccuracy even if the method is carried out carefully
· state the key variables to keep constant
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
